We R Live
item.description:
We R Live

I and Felipe Sodré, through the [ GeoCast Brasil]() channel on YouTube, created this project to share a little bit of our knowledge about handling and visualizing geospatial data through the R language. Always starting from a problem situation, we present the main theoretical concepts and practical approaches for your resolution

item.title: Species Distribution Models: an overview
item.description: Species Distribution Models (SDMs) relate species occurrence data with their environmental conditions to estimate the species’ niche and thus predict new areas of possible distribution. In this lecture, I spoke of the main concepts, input data and applications of this approach in the area of Ecology

item.title: Effects of landscape modification on species richness patterns of fruit-feeding butterflies in Brazilian Atlantic Forest
Fragmented tropical forests lose mutualistic plant-animal interactions
Landscape metrics in R
item.description: In this video, at the invitation of Felipe Sodré, from the channel GeoCast Brasil, I did a rather long live , where I talked about Landscape Ecology and some of the main concepts linked to this discipline, and a practical part about the calculation of landscape metrics using the R language, more specifically using the [landscapemetrics](https: // r- spatialecology.github.io/landscapemetrics/) package. The presentation and codes can be accessed in this GitLab repository.

item.title: Introduction to R Language
item.description: The R language has stood out in recent years (since 2000), as the main tool for data management, visualization and analysis, mainly in the area of Ecology, Psychology, Economics, and more recently, in Data Science. In this course, four introductory themes of this language will be addressed: (i) introduction and operation of the R language and RStudio software, (ii) data structure and manipulation, (iii) introduction to tidyverse, and (iv) data visualization. The workload will be approximately 08 hours, where the theoretical-practical part will be focused, interspersed with exercises to fix the content. At the end of the course, participants are expected to have a general understanding of language functioning and potential applications within the area of ecological data analysis

item.title: Introduction to R Language
item.description: The R language has stood out in recent years (since 2000), as the main tool for data management, visualization and analysis, mainly in the area of Ecology, Psychology, Economics, and more recently, in Data Science. At the end of the course, participants are expected to have a general understanding of language functioning and potential applications within the area of ecological data analysis

item.title: Introduction to Species Distribution Modeling using R Language: theory and practice
item.description: The wide availability of data on biodiversity and environmental variables, has allowed the use of several biogeographic and macroecological analyzes, among them, the species distribution models (MDE). This short course aims to offer a theoretical and practical introduction to the EAW technique, using the R language. First, the main concepts of ecological niche theory (Grinnell, Elton and Hutchinson) and model theory (geographic space (G) , environmental space (E) and Biotic-Abiotic-Movement diagram (BAM)). Following the theoretical part, the main databases (occurrences and environmental variables), types of algorithms (presence and absence - GLM, GAM and Random Forest, only presence - BIOCLIM, Mahalanobis and Gower, and presence and background - Maxent and SVM), model evaluation (ROC, AUC and TSS), thresholds and some model consensus approaches (ensembles). The practical part will be focused on building models using the R language. Initially, an introduction to the programming and handling of spatial data in the R language will be made, using the raster and rgdal packages. Then, it will be presented how to obtain data of occurrences and environmental variables, through spooc and dismo packages. Once the data is acquired, preliminary analyzes will be made, such as selection of occurrences (one point per cell) and variables (correlation, PCA, factor analysis and VIF). Finally, models will be built using the algorithms mentioned above, in addition to calculating the evaluation metrics, using the dismo, randomForest and kernlab packages.

item.title: Predicting the potential hybridization zones between native and invasive marmosets within Neotropical biodiversity hotspots
Land-use changes and the expansion of biofuel crops threaten the giant anteater in southeastern Brazil
Spatial prediction of risk areas for vector transmission of Trypanosoma cruzi in the State of Paraná, southern Brazil
ATLANTIC AMPHIBIANS: Atlantic Forest Amphibian Communities Dataset
item.description: Uncertainties about the diversity and distribution of species is one of the main challenges for conservation biology. The Atlantic Forest Biome is considered one of the most threatened biodiversity hotspots in the world, still holding a high number of amphibian species. In this work, we present a detailed compilation of amphibian communities for the Atlantic Forest. The data set was organized based on a wide geographical delimitation of the biome, encompassing ecotones and areas of Paraguay and Argentina. All community information was obtained from articles, books and unpublished literature (graduation monographs, dissertations and theses). We organize information about: 1) sampled habitat, 2) sampling methods, 3) sampling schedule, 4) sampling effort (initial and final month and year), 5) species composition or abundance, 6) endemism, and 7) location geographic (latitude, longitude, country, state, municipality and specific location). We made taxonomic updates based on data from the Amphibian Species of the World: an Online Reference database, for September 2017. The database was structured from 389 references, sampled between 1940 and 2017, which included 1,163 study, for which there are 17,619 records of 528 species with taxonomic certainty. Of the total records, 14,450 (82%) were classified according to the criterion of endemism to the Atlantic Forest Biome, of which 7,787 (44%) were considered endemic. The most representative methods were: 1) visual or auditory search (82.1%), 2) reproductive site search (20%), 3) trap and fall trap (pitfall, 15.3%), and 4) encounter occasional (14.5%). Among the sampled habitats, none was predominant, although the forest habitat was reported more frequently (40.7%). Most of the study sites had sampling carried out in bodies of water: stream within the forest (33.5%), permanent puddle (30.2%), lake (28.9%), marsh (28.6%) %), temporary pool (27.5%), semi-permanent pool (5.8%) and open water stream (4.5%). Species richness was 15.2 ± 11.3 SD, ranging from 1 to 80 species per location. There was a large sampling bias, with the majority of sampling carried out in the states of São Paulo (38.4%), Paraná (14.2%) and Minas Gerais (10.1%), collectively representing almost 63% of researches. This high bias for these three states may have been due to several reasons: 1) description of two or more study sites for the same reference; 2) historical process of training researchers, in addition to encouraging amphibian sampling research by the BIOTA-FAPESP Program; and 3) numerous herpetological collections, which possibly attracted researchers to carry out taxonomic works. The result of this data compilation generated an overview of the diversity, composition, methods and sampling effort of amphibian communities for the Atlantic Forest Biome, representing a huge effort to fill a knowledge gap about amphibian biodiversity in the Neotropical Region. We hope that these data can be used as a tool for the conservation of this group, in addition to being an important data source for studies of macroecological and biogeographic patterns

item.title: ATLANTIC AMPHIBIANS: a data set of amphibian communities from the Atlantic Forests of South America
A Note on the Territorial Limits of the Atlantic Forest
Effect of Landscape Modifications and Climate Changes on the Persistence of Amphibians in the Atlantic Forest
item.description: Lack of knowledge about the diversity and distribution of species is one of the main challenges for conservation. Allied to this fact, the processes resulting from the modifications of the landscape and climate changes are among the main causes of the loss of world biodiversity, further aggravating the unfamiliar scenario. Amphibians are among the vertebrate groups most sensitive to these changes, mainly due to their particular morphological and ecological characteristics. The Atlantic Forest Biome still has a high diversity of amphibians and is considered one of the most threatened biodiversity hotspots in the world. Therefore, in this project we will seek: (1) to present an assessment of the surveys of the amphibian communities for the Atlantic Forest, their composition and distribution; (2) to investigate how habitat loss and fragmentation on the regional scale can affect the current persistence of amphibians from different reproductive guilds; and (3) to investigate how climate change may affect the future persistence of amphibians of the genus Brachycephalus, considered highly sensitive to these climatic changes. To carry out this project will be used descriptive and spatial analyzes of the surveys of amphibian communities and Ecological Niche Models to find suitable areas for the species. We hope to find an overview of the diversity of amphibian communities and sampling gaps along the Atlantic Forest. In addition, we expect species with aquatic reproductive modes to be more affected by the effects of fragmentation than species with direct development, which will be more affected by habitat loss. Finally, we expect that the areas currently suitable for the occurrence of species of the genus Brachycephalus will suffer a drastic decrease in the future and will be located in higher altitudes

item.title: Efficiency of protected areas in Amazon and Atlantic Forest conservation: A spatio-temporal view
Forest cover influences occurrence of mammalian carnivores within Brazilian Atlantic Forest
Impacts of mining activities on the potential geographic distribution of eastern Brazil mountaintop endemic species
High mammal species turnover in forest patches immersed in biofuel plantations
Effect of fragmentation on the persistence of anuran amphibians within the Atlantic Forest
item.description: Amphibians are sensitive to habitat loss, fragmentation and habitat quality, particularly because their limited mobility over large distances and high dependence of microhabitats for reproduction. The Atlantic Rainforest has about 400 species of amphibians, and 60 to 85% of them are endemic. Nowadays the Atlantic Rainforest is reduced to 11.4% - 16.0% of its original cover, with 80% of fragments < 50 ha, isolated and poorly connected. Therefore, understanding how the process of fragmentation influences the persistence of amphibians within the Atlantic Rainforest is essential for the development of strategic planning for species conservation. This study will evaluate the effect of landscape structure, relief and levels of urbanization at the regional scale on the persistence of species Vitreorana eurygnatha and Vitreorana uranoscopa. These two species are forest-dependent and have aquatic breeding, therefore are extremely susceptible to fragmentation. To carry out the study, the following steps will be taken: (i) model the potential distribution based on the environmental suitability of the species of interest, (ii) identify landscapes with high environmental suitability and surveys with high sampling effort in order to characterize the regional anurofauna, (iii) evaluate the relative contribution of landscape indices (percentage of forest cover, connectivity, relief and urban proximity) to the persistence of species using model selection for multiple competing hypotheses based on Akaike information theory.
